awd_titl_txt: Research in Ring Theory and Noncommutative Algebraic Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The central aim of this research project is the study of various classes of quantum algebras (particularly quantized algebras of functions), with strong focus on both algebraic structure and geometric aspects. These algebras were discovered in the 1980s in the process of solving problems in theoretical quantum physics. They are mathematical systems that model rings of functions on geometric structures as in algebraic geometry (the study of geometric spaces defined by polynomial equations) except that the multiplication is noncommutative. The internal structure of quantum algebras will be intensively investigated, particularly those substructures that correspond to points and geometric subspaces in the classical analogs, together with relations between quantum and classical algebras that are connected via a semiclassical limit (a process in which the noncommutativity tends to zero). These commutative semiclassical limit algebras carry a remnant of the noncommutativity of the associated quantum algebras, recorded in a bilinear form called a Poisson bracket. The work will also pursue the closely related questions about Poisson algebras, as well as the classical-quantum interplay between Poisson semiclassical limits and their quantum counterparts. The research aims both to advance, and to tighten the links among, several highly active mathematical areas -- quantum groups, Poisson algebra, noncommutative algebraic geometry, and cluster theory. In particular, the work will furnish tools to pass insights from one area to the others. 

Specific projects include the exploitation of cluster algebra structures on large classes of quantum and Poisson algebras towards the ideal theory of these algebras. A related effort will go into the construction of more viable bridges over which to shift information back and forth between quantum algebras and their semiclassical limits. Along this line, the investigator conjectures that the prime and primitive spectra of a quantum algebra are homeomorphic to the Poisson-prime and Poisson-primitive spectra of a semiclassical limit, and he will devote major effort towards a confirmation. Other projects target the classical-quantum interplay. The goal is to develop noncommutative versions of properties enjoyed by commutative coordinate rings, prominent among them being catenarity of their prime spectra. The work will explore the conjecture that all quantized coordinate rings enjoy catenarity. These efforts are related to the goal of elucidating the global topological structures of the prime and primitive spectra of quantum algebras. This is aimed at gluing the (already secured) classical pieces of these spectra via auxiliary spaces and maps that are not required in the classical setting. Establishing a specific, detailed format for this gluing and auxiliary data, together with similar, matching formats for the spectra of quantum algebras and semiclassical limits, would yield explicit homeomorphisms between these spectra, and thus establish the conjectured quantum-Poisson interplay.

por.por_cntn:
The PI investigated algebraic systems exhibiting quantum noncommutativity; the latter means that classical commutativity relations of the form xy = yx  for elements x, y of an algebra are replaced by relations such as xy = q yx or xy = yx + (q - q^{-1}) uv where q is a scalar.  Interest in such systems, generalizations of algebras arising in conventional algebraic geometry, is motivated by their numerous applications, e.g., in theoretical physics.  Both algebraic and geometric structure theorems were proved by the PI and his collaborators in this context, and new insights about semiclassical limits of quantum algebras -- where q goes to 1, that is, the classical scenario is approached  -- were obtained.

With the above systems in mind, the PI and M. Yakimov introduced and explored new invariants for graded or filtered algebras; these are effective tools towards deciding whether two given algebras are isomorphic.  For major classes of algebras carrying a Poisson structure, they established the existence of compatible cluster algebra structures, and for important classes of quantum algebras with cluster structures, they also established integral forms for these structures (in which all the structural constants are integer polynomials in q and q^{-1}).  These cluster structures in turn open up further caches of tools to analyze the targeted algebras.  The PI, S. Launois and T.H. Lenagan moreover developed a formula linking prime ideal height and Gelfand-Kirillov dimension in quantum nilpotent algebras.  Still concerning prime ideal spectra, the PI and Launois confirmed the Catenarity Conjecture for large classes of quantum algebras: all saturated chains of prime ideals between two given ones have the same length.  They proceeded to prove the parallel Poisson Catenarity Conjecture for Poisson prime ideals in a major class of Poisson algebras.  Also in this connection, the PI surveyed the current state of knowledge regarding the prime and primitive spectra of quantum algebras.  On a different but related track, he described and classified binomial ideals in quantum tori and quantum affine spaces.  For quantum affine spaces, he and Launois moreover verified several conjectured properties, including properties of their spectra.  In a more restricted setting, namely that of the 2x2 reflection equation algebra, the PI's student E. Ebrahim classified the prime ideals and the finite dimensional irreducible representations, as well as describing the automorphism group.

Along a different line, the PI and B. Huisgen-Zimmermann obtained new insights on geometric aspects of finite dimensional algebras; their results concern parametrizing varieties of representations with fixed dimension vector.  In the case of truncated path algebras, they classified the irreducible components of these varieties in terms of a newly introduced filtration invariant.  They also assembled an extensive survey of related algebro-geometric classification results to date and of generic properties of the representations corresponding to the irreducible components of the parametrizing varieties.
